section.title: Volume encryption supported by the key manager
section.para: We recommend the Key management service (barbican) for storing encryption keys used by the OpenStack volume encryption feature. It can be enabled by updating cinder.conf and nova.conf.

section.title: Initial configuration

procedure.para: Configuration changes need to be made to any nodes running the cinder-volume or nova-compute server.

step.para: Edit the /etc/cinder/cinder.conf file to use Key management service as follows:
Enter a new line directly below [keymgr] with the following: api_class=cinder.keymgr.barbican.BarbicanKeyManager

note.para: Use a '#' prefix to comment out the line in this section that begins with 'fixed_key'.

step.para: Repeat the same steps above to set up the Key management service by editing /etc/nova/nova.conf

section.title: Create an encrypted volume type
section.para: Block Storage volume type assignment provides scheduling to a specific back-end, and can be used to specify actionable information for a back-end storage device.
This example creates a volume type called LUKS and provides configuration information for the storage system to encrypt or decrypt the volume.

step.para: Mark the volume type as encrypted and provide the necessary details. Use --control_location to specify where encryption is performed: front-end (default) or back-end.

screen.userinput: cinder encryption-type-create --cipher aes-xts-plain64 --key_size 512 \ --control_location front-end LUKS nova.volume.encryptors.luks.LuksEncryptor

section.para: Support for creating the volume type in the OpenStack dashboard (horizon) exists today, however support for tagging the type as encrypted and providing the additional information needed is still in review.

section.title: Create an encrypted volume
section.para: Use the OpenStack dashboard (horizon), or the cinder command to create volumes just as you normally would. For an encrypted volume use the LUKS tag, for unencrypted leave the LUKS tag off.

note.para: Due to the issue that some of the volume drivers do not set 'encrypted' flag, attaching of encrypted volumes to a virtual guest will fail, because OpenStack Compute service will not run encryption providers.
